awd_titl_txt: Quantum Simulation of Turbulence with Cold Atoms
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum vortices - an analog of tornadoes - play a key role in the dynamics of neutron stars: the densest objects in the universe on the verge of becoming black holes. Surprisingly, quantum vortices can be studied on earth with ultracold-atom experiments, operating almost a billion times colder than outer space. These experiments can be adjusted to mimic many aspects of neutron stars, and this project will enable them to be used as analog quantum computers to simulate turbulence in nuclear astrophysics. By transcending current limitations of classical computers, this will rapidly accelerate the progress of science, targeting the 40-year old mystery of pulsar glitches. This program combines two of the NSF's Big Ideas, advancing quantum simulations (Quantum Leap) to maximize the return on detector investment (Windows on the Universe). Pulsar glitches might even be heard with the next round of gravitational wave observations at the NSF LIGO facility, informing nuclear physics by providing insight into their microscopic nature. In addition to advancing basic science, this project will explore quantum dynamics with potential applications to quantum devices, and develop accessible programming models to help students and researchers more effectively utilize national investment in high-performance computing (HPC) to advance the pace of scientific discovery. Finally, a superfluid explorer application will be developed to help the public and students appreciate quantum behavior, and better understand the science at the core of the next quantum revolution.

This project will deliver computationally efficient models that accurately describe dynamic quantum effects, including negative-mass hydrodynamics from dispersion relationships engineered with spin-orbit coupled Bose-Einstein condensates. Ultracold atom experiments explore a rich set of phenomena that will be used validate our theoretical techniques, then these techniques will be used to drive the discovery of new phenomena. Extensions of this theory to nuclear physics will ultimately be used to model superfluid vortex dynamics in neutron stars with the goal of understanding pulsar glitches - sudden increases in the spinning of neutron stars even though they continually lose angular momentum. This project will advance a broad range of fields, including atomic physics, condensed matter, non-linear optics, nuclear theory, and nuclear astrophysics. The research will result in publicly available codes for solving problems in quantum dynamics, presented in intuitive and interactive notebooks with video tutorials demonstrating how to use high-level programming languages to drive high-performance computers. These tools will significantly improve the infrastructure for research and education, educating researchers to effectively utilize medium to large scale computing resources for the advancement of science. Through this project, both undergraduate and graduate students will be trained with the analytical and high-performance computational skills to succeed in their future pursuits in academia, at national laboratories, and in industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many fundamental phenomena remain unexplained, awaiting computationally efficient and accurate theories of quantum dynamics. Recent advances in cold atom technology provide a way to validate these theories, broadly impacting fields such as nuclear astrophysics where direct experimental validation is impossible. This project studied quantum simulations in a variety of systems, validating these with cold atom experiments, and applying them to study neutron stars.

Intellectual Merit:

By cooling atoms to almost absolute zero, we were able to exploit their properties as waves to create a new type of quantum sensor - an atom-wave interferometer - that we used to directly image magnetic and gravitational fields. Agreement between experiment and theory validates the computational techniques we use to study these quantum systems. A similar technique was used to design an experimental protocol for measuring superfluid entrainment - the so-called Andreev-Bashkin effect.

Using some the largest supercomputers available, we used validated quantum simulations to study compressible turbulence in fermionic superfluids - the type expected to exist in neutron stars. In these superfluids, vortex dynamics transfers energy from one length scale to another, the hallmark of turbulence. By looking at the structure of the vortex cores, we developed a technique for locally measuring the temperature in the turbulent systems, enabling use to better understand the nature of dissipation in these systems.

Properly calibrated simulations of quantum dynamics are a crucial component of our long-term program to use multi-messenger astronomy as a way to learn about nuclear physics. We performed an analysis of existing gravitational wave and electromagnetic data about neutron stars, and found that current observations are not yet sufficient to distinguish between different nuclear equations of state. One path forward is to understand the quantum turbulence of the type studied here, and make predictions about how the nuclear equation of state will affect phenomena like pulsar glitches that will be measured by future NSF-funded detectors.

Broader Impacts:

Our research was the focus of a Scientific American article "Ultracold Gases Can Probe Neutron Star Guts" by Katie McCormick, in their Knowable Magazine, July 2023, demonstrating the broad appeal of the technical content of this proposal.

13 graduate students (including the completion of 4 Ph.D theses) and 8 undergraduate students (including 3 senior theses and 4 REU students) were trained as part of this program, learning a combination of high-performance computing techniques, and quantum technologies.

We have publicly released our superfluid dynamics codes, including the W-SLDA toolkit which is capable of effectively utilizing the largest computers in the world. These codes demonstrate strong scaling, and fully utilize the GPU accelerators that provide current supercomputers with the majority of their computing power. Our results were performed on some of the most powerful supercomputers available, and required diagonalizing some of the largest matrices to date leading to improvements in the open-source ELPA libraries, broadly benefiting other applications.

To help train students to use these simulations, we have built an interactive superfluid dynamics explorer called super_hydro and accompanying tutorials which takes students from scratch through the process of building a high-performance simulation in python that can utilize GPU acceleration.

To further help students learn, we have released extensive open-source documentation including code-complete figures embracing the idea of reproducible science and computing. These are publicly hosted on Read-The Docs for students, instructors, and interested public to learn about sophisticated techniques, and use for further curriculum development. New courses developed during the period of this grant include core training in Classical Mechanics, Mathematical Methods for Physics, and Quantum Mechanics. We have also developed new courses related to our interdisciplinary iSciMath program on Quantum Computing and Technologies, an interdisciplinary Standard Model course, Learning from Images and Signals, Fractals, and the Art of Estimation.
